awd_titl_txt: International Collaboration in Chemistry: Quantitative analysis of Hydrogen bonding in a membrane milieu
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Alessandro Senes at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, USA, is supported by the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry, for an International Collaboration in Chemistry (ICC) award that comprises an international collaboration with Professor Isiah Arkin, of The Hebrew University of Jerusalem in Israel, who is supported by The Israel Bi-national Science Foundation.

The aim of this project is to investigate one of the forces responsible for the shapes of membrane proteins. Integral membrane proteins are embedded within cellular membranes, at the boundaries between the cell and the outside environments, as well as within the membrane of intracellular compartments called organelles, where these proteins perform a wide variety of essential functions.  In order to perform these functions, membrane proteins are required to fold into a defined three-dimensional structure and often associate with other membrane proteins.  The forces that allow membrane proteins to fold into a particular three-dimensional structure and associate with each other are still not well understood.  This research will elucidate the specific role played by one of these fundamental forces - hydrogen bonding - in the folding and association of membrane proteins.  The outcomes of this proposal will be used to better understand a wide variety of important biological systems. The project will have a broader impact through research training in an interdisciplinary environment. The interdisciplinary nature of the work will provide graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, as well as early career students, with opportunities to acquire inter-disciplinary training in a variety of experimental and computational methods. In addition, a broader impact is achieved through providing high school students with computational skills and outreach efforts to inform the public of the importance of multidisciplinary research in the advancement of science.

The research in this project addresses quantitatively the important question of the contribution of hydrogen bonding to stability and interaction specificity in membrane proteins, with the use of a unique combination of advanced experimental and computational approaches. Isotope-edited FTIR spectroscopy coupled with DFT calculations will be used to analyze the specific energetics of individual hydrogen bonds in interacting transmembrane alpha-helices. In parallel, the overall thermodynamic stability of association of the same alpha-helices will be assessed by using a combination of FRET and analytical ultracentrifugation.  This research will be accomplished using a structural framework provided by advanced computational modeling, initially in the context of characterized model systems, and later using predicted oligomerizing helices from single-pass membrane proteins, as well as membrane proteins of known structure. This approach will allow exploration of the relationship between the strength of individual hydrogen bonds and their effective contribution to complex formation.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project objective was to understand the contributions of hydrogen bonding to the association of membrane proteins. Hydrogen bonding is a defining feature of bio-macromolecular structure. Yet, its contribution to stability and interaction specificity in membrane proteins is still unclear. In this research, we addressed this important question quantitatively using a unique combination of advanced experimental and computational approaches. The project integrates computational and experimental methods, using well-behaved transmembrane complexes as major model systems.  These include the FtsLB complex of the bacterial divisome, as an example of membrane protein whose interaction is stabilized by a typical hydrogen bond in which the donor is a nitrogen or oxygen atom. Additionally, the project focused on protein whose association occurs through the formation of so-called GASright motifs, which are examples of transmembrane dimer mediated by weak hydrogen bonds in which the donor is a carbon atom (Cα–H∙∙∙O=C).

We derived a molecular model of the FtsLB complex from co-evolutionary constraints, which we validated in vitro and in vivo with biophysical and biological experiments.  The experiments indicated that the hydrogen bonding network in the transmembrane region of FtsLB can rearrange in multiple configurations, interacting with different acceptor side chains on the opposing transmembrane helix. Such plasticity may be important for supporting conformational changes necessary for the function of the FtsLB complex.

The characterization of weak Cα–H∙∙∙O=C hydrogen bonding in GASright motifs was guided by our molecular prediction program CATM. We discovered that the GASright motif is uniquely optimized for the formation of networks of weak hydrogen bonds. We also obtained evidence supporting the theory that these weak hydrogen bonds overall contribute significantly to the stability of these complex, in combination with extensive packing (van der Waals interactions).

The project has supported several graduate students, providing them with substantial independent research experience, as well as with opportunities for professional development and mentoring opportunities. Additionally, the project supported early-stage (high-school) students through a cooperation with the Youth Apprenticeship Program in Biotechnology (YAP-Biotechnology), in partnership with the non-profit BioPharmaceutical Technology Center Institute (BTC). Each high-school student attended the laboratory for 450 hours, receiving training in basic biochemical methods and principles, which allowed them to develop an appreciation about how biochemical research is conducted. Finally, the project also supported an outreach activity, a Teacher Workshop in bioinformatics, hosted by BTC. We had 15 registrants for the workshop, including teachers from Illinois, Iowa, and Minnesota Technical College Instructor. The goal of this activity is to provide teachers with understanding the use of various bioinformatics tools available online, tools can be potentially later introduced into their classroom to support their teaching of biology and biotechnology to high-school students.

 


Last Modified: 11/08/2019
Modified by: Alessandro Senes

The project objective was to understand the contributions of hydrogen bonding to the association of membrane proteins. Hydrogen bonding is a defining feature of bio-macromolecular structure. Yet, its contribution to stability and interaction specificity in membrane proteins is still unclear. In this research, we addressed this important question quantitatively using a unique combination of advanced experimental and computational approaches. The project integrates computational and experimental methods, using well-behaved transmembrane complexes as major model systems.  These include the FtsLB complex of the bacterial divisome, as an example of membrane protein whose interaction is stabilized by a typical hydrogen bond in which the donor is a nitrogen or oxygen atom. Additionally, the project focused on protein whose association occurs through the formation of so-called GASright motifs, which are examples of transmembrane dimer mediated by weak hydrogen bonds in which the donor is a carbon atom (Cα–H∙∙∙O=C).

The project has supported several graduate students, providing them with substantial independent research experience, as well as with opportunities for professional development and mentoring opportunities. Additionally, the project supported early-stage (high-school) students through a cooperation with the Youth Apprenticeship Program in Biotechnology (YAP-Biotechnology), in partnership with the non-profit BioPharmaceutical Technology Center Institute (BTC). We had 15 registrants for the workshop, including teachers from Illinois, Iowa, and Minnesota Technical College Instructor. The goal of this activity is to provide teachers with understanding the use of various bioinformatics tools available online, tools can be potentially later introduced into their classroom to support their teaching of biology and biotechnology to high-school students.
